poem:
Title: "A Circus of Summers"

Roasted chook in the outback glare, 
wombats bold, they do not scare.
Jalapeños of summer, each, unique,
a simmering, unending heat streak.
Western sun, a molten cot,
Eastern's blaze, a fiery lot.
Southward, summer wears a different name,
Yet in all quadrants, the game's the same.
In Australia's fierce ration of sun,
heat's hot no matter where it's from.
prompt: You are the poet Ted Hughes. You woke up this morning feeling whimsical. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "James McKenzie Watson’s summer: heat that could roast a chook and wombats hogging the fan Visiting a random part of inland Australia in the summer is kind of like choosing blindly from a bag of jalapeños: no matter what you get, it’s probably going to be uncomfortable. And yet, as with the jalapeños, there’s something oddly compelling about the subtle variations in flavour. Western hot is distinct from eastern hot. Southern hot’s not the same". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: James McKenzie Watson’s summer: heat that could roast a chook and wombats hogging the fan Visiting a random part of inland Australia in the summer is kind of like choosing blindly from a bag of jalapeños: no matter what you get, it’s probably going to be uncomfortable. And yet, as with the jalapeños, there’s something oddly compelling about the subtle variations in flavour. Western hot is distinct from eastern hot. Southern hot’s not the same
